Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 05:44PM olisad wrote: Hi Debra. My favorite friend has liver mets. I am a big reader and am always floating articles to her. The phase I clinical trial has wrapped on this particular drug, PV-10. Something to tuck in the back of your mind (or write down, Tanya has to write everything down - chemo brain :) It is early but results were promising and may move to a phase II trial. Tanya has had regression with Tax/Ad, stability with TEMP (which is tamoxifen along with etoposide, mitoxantrone, and platinol) and regression again with Xeloda. Also a link to a recent article about liver resection. Something to talk about. Hugs, Lisa Clinical Trial Info newsblaze.com/story/2011012705...  clinicaltrials.gov/archive/NCT...  Liver resection article www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingCo...

Posts.Content: olisad wrote: I have been able to read and search each individual item, but haven't found anyone on the site that has posted about TEMP. T's (twoshoes) last Taxotere/Adriamycin infusion was today. With great success so far! Next scan is just before the TEMP at the end of the month. Tax/Ad really kicked the cancer in the balls! Hope it is continuing to do so. Wondering if any of you have experience with the next round. She will have the TEMP infusions 3 consecutive days, every 3 weeks for 4 weeks. Today she sits at the top of the mountain (at least the first mountain). Halfway done! Any advise, tips, thoughts or pointers in the right direction, greatly appreciated. Thanks for everything. Lisa Best friend has mets to liver, bone, brain. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Etoposide Platinol Mitoxantrone olisad olisad

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 11:47PM - edited Jun 8, 2010 11:51PM by olisad Hi joaniji, ignorant? Come on. That's me. I just ask a ton of questions. TEMP is the acronym for the next batch of drugs. Tamoxifen (the hormonal) then 3 chemos (etoposide, platinol and mitoxantrone). Through all of the chemo she has continued with tamox. She is ER+, PR- and HER2- and IDC. She had a 7cm tumor in her lung, 40+ spots on her liver and one on her adrenal gland. Her first scan showed excellent results (after 2 rounds of the taxotere and adriamycin) – lung clear, liver and adrenal gland lesions size significantly reduced (over 50%). Next scan is in 3 weeks. She will go for 3 consecutive days. Day 1 EMP, day 2 EP, day 3 E. I have read about each of these separate, but not about them given all at once. Or at least haven't yet found any info on it. Probably need a few more days of googling. Just that everyone here is a great place to start, so much knowledge and such willingness to share. I am the question asker of the two of us. I already have some for her next onc visit. Like, why this combo? And where can I read more about them? Hope that is the info you were looking for. And if you have questions, I will ask and find some answers. Thanks for the warm wishes. Lisa Edit: Realized I have the title as TEPM, not TEMP. Ugh. Apologies, sometimes my fingers work faster than my brain.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Etoposide Platinol Mitoxantrone olisad olisad

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 03:49AM olisad wrote: I drive my boys home from school. They are all characters. Funny kids. Last spring my oldest, JT, got the 5th grade your-bodies-are-changing-and-here-is-a-politically-correct-we'll-just-touch-on-each-area-a-tiny-bit talk. JT jumped in the car all talky, "Mom, mom I think I know why Sethy is having accidents!" Really? I was so interested,! We've tried everything short of meds, (not touching those), buzzers, plastic sheets, setting the alarm to wake us up to wake him up to go pee, trick his body into thinking day is night and night is day, ugh. Everything. Imagine my excitement. He began, "Today was the talk and well, I think, maybe he has this thing called puberty. We learned that puberty gives you these dreams....." Sethy is seven. Kids are such helpers :)

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 12:16PM olisad wrote: Hello Marybe. My friend Tanya is on Xeloda, and is doing quite well. Started in November and is seeing regression. It is slow, but it is working. She feels good. Tired at the end of each week on, (she takes 1500mg 2x a day for 7 days and then has 7 days off), but other than that she really is holding her own. It took a few cycles to get the dosage right and since her side effects are scarce. We were talking with her onc last week and he wants her to consider adding something to Xeloda later in the summer to see if there could be a quicker, more dramatic result. Gemzar was when he mentioned, a small dose once a month. In reading I found that Taxotere and Ixempra with Xeloda also have increased effectiveness. Anyhow, I guess my thought is if you're feeling good, and summer is a coming, why not start with Xeloda? Something considered to be relatively mild, but something that works on both bone and liver, and something that can be amped up with an additional chemo if you are not happy with the results. Thanks for letting me ring in. Lisa

Posts.Content: olisad wrote: An update on twoshoes. She needs some encouragement and a smile. Switched to a new chemo regime after kicking cancer in the balls with taxotere and adriamycin – 12 weeks that zapped a 7cm lung tumor all gone :) and reduced the size and number of liver mets rather significantly. We are both a bit statistics challenged and can't figure if the meaning is reduced by 75% or reduced to 75% of the size/number. Even the nurses couldn't figure the wording. No matter they responded well and her onc will clarrify on Tuesday. Now using an older combo, TEMP, tamoxifin with etoposide, mitoxantrone and platinol, for 12 more weeks. And after only 2 weeks had her first scan. Stable. She will pepper her onc with questions on Tuesday. In the meantime, got a text from her that just said stable. And then another that said a little bummed. Stable is good. Not what she was hoping for but I think stable is good. Right? Best friend has mets to liver, bone, brain. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: olisad wrote: The cliche that things come in groups of three rang true last week. 1. T's birthday, always good news. Though she believes number one was winning a flat screen TV in a drawing. I think birthday. 2. After over a year of apply, deny, re-apply, re-deny, written appeals, and written denials, a hearing on her SSDI came and went without denial! SSDI approved! Even without the mandatory amount of work credits. Tamoxifan was deemed enough to inhibit T's ability to work fulltime. If any of you would like the details PM me and happy to share. 3. Reduction in liver tumors indicates positive response to treatement. 14 months of chemo and in May T decided on a chemo break and try Faslodex. Well, hello Faslodex... Going to float around in the fantastic news cloud for as long as I can. Hugs to you all :) Lisa  Best friend has mets to liver, bone, brain. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 01:16AM olisad wrote: Some days you will feel like a punching bag. Some days like a doormat. Some days you will want to scream or cry and wish it all away. Some days you will be filled with hope. Some days not so much. Everyone above has it correct. You are her friend. Stupid effing cancer has nothing to do with it. Treat her like you would a friend. It is overwhelming to think about. It is also overwhelming to be hit with a tidal wave of help. You'll see what she wants and needs. You'll be more in tune to it than ever before. Read here. Research here. Ask questions here. Tanya is living with stupid effing cancer because of the loving, giving men and women on these boards. If she is comfortable with it, go to treatment with her. Sit. Gab. Laugh. Help make her feel like she has a tether to a regular life. I adore my pal Tanya. And we both cherish the time where we feel like two silly girls doing all kinds of silly things. And most important, don't forget about you. Find someone you can lean on. It is difficult, this crazy journey, but very much worth it. Very, very much. Xo Lisa

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 08:24PM olisad wrote: I agree, this theory is for all stages. The sponsor of this petition is Stage IV, but I don't believe she intends it to be limited to that. This really is about the entire disease. I agree that individual letter writing is a great idea. Personalized – not just a copy of the petition– telling them why this is important to you and your community and our healthcare system. Sending notes to your Senators, Congressman and Governor is easy. A quick Google and you have their address. What elected officials don't want are unhappy, motivated constituents. Could I suggest taking it a step further? I know that these boards and Facebook and the like are great places to connect and to touch base with masses, but a personalized letter to a friend goes so much further. If someone asked me to write a letter for an important cause and gave me compelling reasons why, I would certainly do so. I believe most would as well. If asked, I would pass along that story and information and ask my friends to do the same. If a group does that and continues to ask, it has the potential to go far. What Dr. Tuohy is looking for is exposure and for some foundation, organization, their partners or corporate sponsors, and even congress to fund his study. To take it to human trials. Even people you don't know, celebrities, sports figures, philanthropists, reporters, etc., may react to a letter. You just don't know until you try. I also believe there are many, many worthwhile theories and researchers that would benefit from a cage rattling. It just so happens, that here on this board, it started with Dr. Tuohy.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 10:24AM olisad wrote: Elaine, immediately after starting this thread I kept thinking there are so many people that would be thrilled with stable. How are you all going to react to this? Will it make any of you angry or sad? The last few weeks here, there have been post after post of progression tales. Twoshoes has only been part of the stage iv world for 4 months. I think she still is wrapping her head around the entire dx. That there isn't a magic pill or treatment that makes it just go away. Her attitude is so positive and she always has a brave face for friends and family. It is her nature. This news just slowed her down a bit. Deflated her a bit. Expectations we attach to ourselves are tough things, especially when you have no control over their outcome.  I agree she needs to take time to put all of this into context, to breath a bit and understand that the path she is on is a long one. I just want her to know there are so many behind her, helping her up when she is down. Thanks for your thoughtful and though provoking post. Lisa

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 04:42PM olisad wrote: I am a big fan of the Showtime shows, Dexter, Weeds, Nurse Jackie, and this one is confusing me because I don't feel like I am interested or attracted to Cathy. And it boggles me, because i am interested/attracted to all of the 'normal' leads in those other shows, you know, the serial killer crime lab guy, the drug dealing gun toting widow, and the pill popping cheatin' nurse. I love them all. But with Cathy, I can't figure what it is. I like her relationship with her student Andrea. I think Cathy and her neighbor are similar characters, there is a loneliness that her neighbor has learned to live with and that Cathy is just beginning to find how to herself. Look forward to see where that storyline goes. Best giggle out loud moment was when she was outside sunning and her husband came by. That exchange was funny. I do understand her want to spend more time with her son and even brother and the husband, blech, that actor just gives me the creeps. He was cast perfectly. :) Looking forward to episode 3.
Posts.Title: The Big C -episode 2 Fitztwins olisad

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2010 10:18PM olisad wrote: Jennifer, I was a weepy mess! I stood in the crowd trying to control the tears and eventually just gave up. Water works. The pomp and circumstance and commercialism was odd. I understand why it's there, the squeaky wheel and all. I've read posts here and until today didn't understand some not liking pink, the man, etc. I think I understand that a little bit more now. Today was important for me. It is a run I will always do. To remember and reflect.

Posts.Title: How to support my best friend.. stupidcancer blondiex46

Posts.Content: olisad wrote: Today was the SGK run in Milwaukee. Never attended. Never really ever thought anything about breast cancer before March. It was not part of my world. Decided it would be a good reflective day. Alone. Just run. Think. Remember. The months I have been lurking around this board all came together today. Ford and pink, yogurt and pink, furniture and pink, vendors. It seemed so weird. I get it now. (The  artist in me loved the pink water fountains.) It was an emotional morning. Names on t-shirts. Families walking and holding hands. A mom sitting on her lawn chair alone on a city corner with a sign that just said "Thank You." I thought selfishly about me for a while. And then Tanya. And then Cheryl, Linda, Kendra...  And then about so many of you who have shared your experiences, and laughs, and rants and cries. Or have written a kind note. Or offered sage advice. Or who said it straight, when maybe I was looking for a sugar coated response. Someone here wrote a thank you recently to "people I will likely never meet but cherish nevertheless." I can't think of a way to say it better. Thank You. xo Lisa Best friend has mets to liver, bone, brain. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 10:22PM olisad wrote: Here is another idea. Standuptocancer.org. I realize this campaign is very Hollywood, and very broad, but if you'd want to get Dr Tuohy's work noticed rather quickly, light up their forum. This broadcast is September 10, 2010 and most of their forum doesn't look like it has been touched for months and months. A sudden burst of women discussing their story and the hope of new theories and research could help shed more light onto that work. Also, a note to any of the founders could possibly go a long way. There is also a place to share your story. The links are below. First forum, then founders, then submit a story. Hope this isn't violating any rules or stepping on any toes. Merely a suggestion. Lisa www.standup2cancer.org/magazin...  http://www.standup2cancer.org/su2c/about_us/co_founders www.standup2cancer.org/contact

Posts.Title: Please share how breastcancer.org has impacted you.... Moderators BouncingBetties

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2015 11:22PM olisad wrote: hi nancy. Such beautiful blues (the hues). And some crappy ones as well (the downs). I hope you begin to feel better. I was remembering a treatment of Tanya's. It was used for metastatic melanoma, but Dr. L tried it and Tanya had great success. It is called the Dartmouth Regime. Here is a link. It is Carmustine, Cisplatin, Dacarbazine and Tamoxifen. Another combo Tanya did early on was TEMP. Tamoxifen, Etoposide, Mitoxantrone and Cisplatin. Here is that link. It's old stuff, but Dr. L rocked it old school. Feel better. lisa
